Article PS-PPh2 tethered Pt single atoms promoted by SnCl2 as highly efficient and regio-selective catalysts for the hydroformylation of higher α-alkenes Zhounan Yu a b Leilei Zhang a * Yuanlong Tan a b Rizheng Jing a b Hongchen Cao a b Caiyi Lou b c Rile Ge a d Junhu Wang a d Aiqin Wang a * Tao Zhang a a CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c National Engineering Research Center of Lower-Carbon Catalysis Technology, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China National Engineering Research Center of Lower-Carbon Catalysis Technology Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China National Engineering Research Center of Lower-Carbon Catalysis Technology, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China d Mössbauer Effect Data Center, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Mössbauer Effect Data Center Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China Mössbauer Effect Data Center, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China * Corresponding author Rh-P complexes have been widely used as catalysts for hydroformylation reactions. The extremely high price of Rh and its scarce reserves have prompted the exploration of the alternatives. In this study, we reported that Pt/PS-PPh2 single-atom catalysts promoted by SnCl2 were highly efficient and selective for the hydroformylation of higher α-alkenes. A broad scope of substrates (i.e., C6–C12) were smoothly converted to the corresponding linear aldehydes with high yields under reaction conditions of 90–120 °C and 4–6 MPa syngas. The turnover frequency (TOF) was comparable to homogeneous Pt-Sn catalysts, and the linear/branched ratio reached as high as > 20. In addition, the catalyst could be reused with the extra addition of SnCl2. The promotional role of SnCl2 was elucidated by quasi-in situ X-ray adsorption fine structure, Fourier transform infrared, and Mössbauer spectroscopy. It was discovered that SnCl2 was transformed into Sn(dioxane)Cl3 − species coordinated to Pt as a moderately electron-donating ligand, which, together with the phosphine group, stabilized mononuclear Pt (I) species against reduction and aggregation. Graphical Abstract Bimetallic Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 catalyst exhibited high catalytic performance in the hydroformylation of higher alkenes. Sn(dioxane)Cl3 - species derived from SnCl2, together with the PPh2 ligand, were discovered to stabilize mononuclear Pt(I) species against reduction and aggregation. Keywords Hydroformylation reaction Platinum-tin catalyst Higher alkenes Regio-selectivity Single-atom catalyst 1 Introduction Hydroformylation reaction, by which widely available alkenes can be transformed into value-added aldehydes in the presence of CO and H2 (C n H2n + CO + H2 → C n+1H2n+2O), is of great significance in fine chemicals industries [1–4]. Currently, Co and Rh are the catalytically active metal of choice for this transformation [4–9]. HCo(CO)4 and HCo(CO)3(PR3) were the original industrial catalysts for hydroformylation reactions which were able to convert linear alkenes, and branched and internal alkenes into mainly linear product aldehydes [10,11]. The reactions usually proceed under high pressures (10–30 MPa) due to the ease of decomposition of cobalt carbonyls into cobalt metal, although the usage of alkylphosphines as ligands could improve the stability and thus relatively low pressure (5–15 MPa) is required [10]. The electron-donating ligands, on the other hand, led to stronger Co–CO bonding and consequently compromised the reactivity (TOF = 12–30 h−1 vs. 300–1200 h−1 of HCo(CO)4). Notably, Stanley and coworkers recently made great advances in Co-based catalysts for hydroformylation reaction. They invented a kind of cationic Co(II) bisphosphine hydrido-carbonyl catalysts which demonstrated surprisingly high catalytic activity (TOF = 600–3600 h−1), exceptionally stability (> 336 h), and also high linear-to-branched (l/b = 58) regioselectivity for the hydroformylation of branched internal alkenes, although for simple 1-alkenes, the l/b ratio of the product aldehydes was low [12,13]. The Rh complexes HRh(CO)4 and HRh(CO)(PPh3)2, on the other hand, were hundreds of times more active than the Co based counterparts for the hydroformylation reaction, and the reactions can be run under mild conditions (e.g., T < 120 °C and P < 2 MPa) [5,14,15]. Moreover, the feedstock utilization is much better over Rh catalysts, which was in sharp contrast to Co catalysts where up to 20%–30% paraffin is yielded as by-products [10]. Nonetheless, Rh is extremely expensive (€3097/oz, over 4-fold that of €713/oz Pt, Heraeus Precious Metals Prices & Reports) and scarce in resources, and a large excess of PPh3 ligands (P/Rh = 400–1600/1, molar ratio) is necessary to maintain the high regio-selectivity and stability, owing to the facile dissociation of the PPh3 ligand from Rh as well as the Rh-induced phosphine fragmentation reactions. Moreover, although Rh catalysts began to replace Co catalysts in hydroformylation of propene and butene in the 1970s [16], there have been limited precedents on Rh-catalysed hydroformylation of higher alkenes. Instead, for the hydroformylation of higher alkenes (C6+) which are highly desirable to produce higher alcohols for detergents and plasticizers, Co-based catalysts are still widely employed although suffering from harsh reaction conditions and only moderate chemo- and regio-selectivity [17–19]. To tackle these limits, great efforts have been devoted to developing non-rhodium alternative catalysts (such as Ru, Pt, Ir, and Pd) for the hydroformylation of higher alkenes [20–23]. For instance, Corma and coworkers reported N-doped carbonaceous material loaded Ru catalysts for hydroformylation of 1-hexene. They found Ru clusters with a size of ~1 nm showed high selectivity for linear aldehydes, yet the catalytic activity was inferior to the Rh counterparts [24]. Among others, the heterobimetallic Pt-Sn catalysts showed great promise owing to their relatively low cost, mild reaction conditions, and exceptionally high regio-selectivity [25,26]. Moreover, in the field of highly demanding asymmetric hydroformylation, Pt-Sn catalysts also gave satisfactory performance [27,28]. To overcome the weakness of difficult separation and recycling, attempts were also made to immobilize Pt-Sn catalysts onto polymers or inorganic metal oxides [28–30]. For instance, Stille and coworkers fabricated phosphine ligand built-in organic polymer supported Pt-Sn catalysts, which afforded high selectivity to the branched aldehydes in the asymmetric hydroformylation. Nevertheless, tedious procedures were required for the catalyst preparation [28]. Piscina and coworkers [29] used SiO2, Al2O3, and MgO to load Pt-Sn complexes, of which the Pt-Sn/SiO2 sample demonstrated high catalytic activity in the hydroformylation of 1-pentene, whereas the other two were inactive. Davies et al. [30] studied the catalytic performance of MCM-41 supported [PtCl2L2]-SnCl2 catalyst for the hydroformylation of 1-hexene in supercritical carbon dioxide. It was discovered the regio-selectivity of [PtCl2L2]-SnCl2/MCM-41 far exceeded that of MCM-41 supported Rh complex. In these examples, in spite of the promising regio-selectivity obtained, the exact function of SnCl2 as a co-catalyst in the reaction is still not fully understood. It has been reported that SnCl2 might serve as Lewis acid to promote the CO insertion step in the catalytic cycle [31,32], or act as a ligand to facilitate the olefin insertion into the Pt–H bond [33], or just behave as the counterion in the form of SnCl3 − during the catalysis [34,35]. Moreover, it is highly desirable to develop more facile and low-cost approach to fabricate robust and regio-selective Pt-Sn catalyst for practical applications. In this study, we used the commercially available PPh2-grafted polystyrene (PS-PPh2) to load Pt(acac)2 and SnCl2, whereby an efficient and high regio-selective catalyst for hydroformylation of higher alkenes was fabricated. A broad scope of substrates (C6 =–C12 =) was converted smoothly to the corresponding aldehydes with high linear/branched region-selectivity under reaction conditions of 90–120 °C and 4–6 MPa syngas. Moreover, the catalytic mechanism of Pt-Sn catalysts was studied by quasi-in situ XAFS, FTIR, and Mössbauer spectroscopy. It has been for the first time discovered that SnCl2 was transformed into a moderately electron-donating ligand Sn(dioxane)Cl3 −, which together with the phosphine ligands, stabilized the single-site Pt(I) active species against reduction and aggregation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Triphenylphosphine resin (PS-PPh2, 1% DVB, 200–400 mesh) with a P loading of 1.25 mmol/g was purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific. Acetylacetone platinum (Pt(acac)2, 97%), rhodium acetylacetonate (Rh(acac)3, 97%), palladium acetylacetonate (Pd(acac)2, 99%), tin(II) chloride dehydrate (SnCl2·2H2O, 98 %), triphenylphosphine (PPh3, 99%), dodecane (99%), n-hexane (99%) and all of the alkenes used (> 97%) were obtained from Aladdin. The solvents, i.e., 1,4-dioxane (99%), cyclohexane (99%) and toluene (98%) were purchased from Guanghua Sci-Tech Co., Ltd. Gold chloride trihydrate (HAuCl4·3H2O, 99.99%), iron chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, 99%), and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 99%) were obtained from Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The alkenes were pre-treated over a short Al2O3 column to remove the peroxide impurities in some cases noted [13] and all the other reagents were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Pt/PS-PPh2 catalyst was prepared by an impregnation method. Taking 4.7Pt/PS-PPh2 as an example, 1.0 g PS-PPh2 and 0.161 g Pt(acac)2 were added into 25 mL 1,4-dioxane. After being thoroughly purged with argon, the mixture was vigorously stirred at 90 °C for 2 h under the protection Ar, followed by filtration and washing with 1,4-dioxane. The solid was dried at 80 °C overnight and denoted as “4.7Pt/PS-PPh2”. The other catalysts were prepared using a similar procedure except for the addition of different amounts of Pt(acac)2, or using different metal precursors (i.e., Rh(acac)3, Pd(acac)2, and HAuCl4·3H2O). 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement The hydroformylation reaction was conducted in an autoclave with Teflon lining. For the reaction catalysed by the Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 sample, 0.1 g 4.7Pt/PS-PPh2 was added into 8 ml 1,4-dioxane (as the solvent), followed by the addition of 0.027 g SnCl2·2H2O, 4 mmol alkene (Pt: reactant = 1:166, molar ratio), and 3 mmol of dodecane (as an internal standard). After being flushed with N2 for three times, the reactor was charged with 4 MPa syngas (CO/H2 = 1/1, v/v), and the reaction was allowed to proceed at 90 °C for 8 h. Alternatively, when homogeneous complex PtSn10(PPh3)1 was used as the catalyst, 0.01 g of Pt(acac)2, 0.25 mmol SnCl2·2H2O, 0.025 mmol PPh3, 6 mL 1,4-dioxane, 0.025 mol alkene (Pt: reactant = 1:1000, molar ratio) and 3 mmol of dodecane were added into the reactor. The identification of the product was carried out on Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS). The quantitative analysis was performed on an Agilent 7890 B gas chromatograph equipped with an automated sampling system, an HP-5 capillary column with dimensions of 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm, and a Flame Ionization Detector (FID). The hot filtration experiment was carried out on the home-made setup where two 25 mL stainless steel autoclave was connected (Fig. S1), of which autoclave-1 was equipped with a filter tube [36]. 0.041 g SnCl2·2H2O, 6 mmol 1-hexene, 4.5 mmol dodecane (as an internal standard), 0.15 g 4.7Pt/PS-PPh2 (Pt: reactant = 1:166, molar ratio), and 12 mL 1,4-dioxane was added to autoclave-1, and then both autoclaves were purged by N2 for 3 times. After the valve between autoclave-1 and autoclave-2 was closed, autoclave-1 was charged with 4 MPa syngas (CO/H2 = 1/1, v/v), and the mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 2 h. Upon opening the valve, the reaction mixture flowed rapidly into the filter tube, by which the filtrate liquid was transferred into autoclave-2 pre-heated to 90 °C, and the final pressure of the system was maintained at 1 MPa. After the valve was closed again, autoclave-2 was charged with syngas to 4 MPa and the reaction was allowed to run for 4 h at 90 °C. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed at Perkin-Elmer Optima 3300 DV ICP instrument. Before the examination, the precisely weighted sample was calcined under static air at 300 °C for 2 h, and the residue was dissolved with hot concentrated nitric acid and finally the solution was diluted into a volumetric flask. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were carried out on a PANalytcal X'pert diffractometer, utilizing a Cu-Kα radiation source. The operational parameters were set at 40 kV and 40 mA. The diffraction angles (2θ) spanned from 10° to 80°. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) photographs were captured using a JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope (TEM), operating at an energy level of 200 kV. A minimal amount of the powdered sample was dispersed in ethanol by ultrasonication. Subsequently, a few droplets of this mixture were placed onto a holey carbon-coated copper TEM grid. Solid-state 31P magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (31P MAS NMR) measurements were conducted using a Bruker Avance NEO 500 WB spectrometer with a 500.13 MHz 1H resonance. The measurements were acquired on a 3.2 mm DVT double resonance MAS probe, with a single 3.3 μs π/2 excitation pulse at a 20 kHz spinning rate. The recycle delay was typically 80 s. The chemical shifts were referenced to 85% H3PO4. The 119Sn Mössbauer spectra were recorded using a Topologic Systems MFD-500AV-04 low-temperature Sn-119 Mössbauer spectrometer, with a Ca119mSnO3 monochromatic radiation source and a Na(I) sodium iodide scintillation crystal detector. The spectra of liquid samples were recorded at –196 °C. The isomer shift (IS) value was calibrated using CaSnO3. In order to improve the quality of the spectra, the concentrations of the samples were enhanced by 4-fold. Typically, 0.04 g Pt(acac)2, 0.23 g SnCl2·2H2O, 0.01 g PPh3, and 0.01 mol 1-hexene were added into 6 mL 1,4-dioxane. For the sample denoted as “before reaction”, the solution was allowed to stir in an autoclave at 90 °C for 1 h under 3 MPa N2. For the other one denoted as “after reaction”, the solution was stirred at 90 °C for 8 h under 6 MPa Syngas (CO:H2 = 1:1, v/v). After cooling to room temperature and the reactant gas was discharged, the two solutions were respectively sealed into the thermoplastic bags, frozen with liquid nitrogen, and fixed on the sample holder. After that, the system was evacuated until a pressure of 10−5 mbar was reached, and then liquid nitrogen was injected to maintain an environmental temperature of –196 °C. MössWinn software was used to analyze the spectrum, and Lorentzian curves and the least squares method were used for curve fitting. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), including extended X-ray adsorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES), was conducted at the BL14W1 beamline of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). Powders of 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2-spent solid catalyst were filled into a polytetrafluoroethylene mold with an inner diameter of 10 mm before the test, while the three homogeneous catalysts (i.e., PtSn2(PPh3)2, Pt(PPh3)2, and PtSn2) were measured in the form of solution directly after reaction. Taking the PtSn2(PPh3)2 sample as an example, 0.042 g of Pt(acac)2, 0.048 g of SnCl2·2H2O, 0.018 g of PPh3, and 2 mL of 1-hexene were added into 6 ml 1,4-dioxane, and the mixture was allowed to stir in an autoclave at 90 °C for 8 h under 6 MPa Syngas (CO: H2 = 1:1, v/v). After cooling to room temperature and the reactant gas was discharged, the solution was immediately sealed into a thermoplastic bag and subjected to the measurement. All data were collected at room temperature under transmission mode and processed with the Athena software package. The CO-adsorption Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Equinox 70 spectrometer with a DTGS detector. The pre-treatment of the three samples (i.e., PtSn2(PPh3)2, Pt(PPh3)2, Sn2(PPh3)2) was quite similar to that in XAS measurements. After that, 0.5 mL of solution was dripped onto a potassium bromide sheet to record the spectra. The 1,4-dioxane adsorption Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra on different samples (i.e., PS-PPh2, 4.7Pt/PS-PPh2 and 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2) were recorded with MCT detector with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The background spectra were collected after the samples were pre-treated at 120 °C with 50 sccm He for 0.5 h and cooled to 90 °C. Subsequently, 1,4-dioxane was introduced into the cell by He bubbling and the spectra were collected at a given time interval until the intensity was no longer increased at 90 °C. Then the cell was purged by He until the spectra intensity was no longer decreased. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 31P MAS NMR characterization of the catalyst Solid-state 31P MAS NMR was employed to probe into the coordination nature of Pt with the PPh2 group in the Pt/PS-PPh2 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 1 , only one resonance peak at −4.5 ppm appeared in the spectrum of the Pt-free PS-PPh2 support. By contrast, two resonance peaks were present after the loading of Pt, of which the one with identical chemical shift to that of PS-PPh2 was attributed to free phosphine, whereas the other one at 22.6 ppm was ascribed to phosphine coordinated to Pt species [37]. The ratio of integral area of the two peaks (A-4.5:A22.6) is ~0.28/1, by which, together with the loading of phosphine (1.25 mmol/g) and Pt (0.24 mmol/g), the coordination number of Pt-P is estimated to be approximately 4, in good agreement with the XAFS curve-fitting results (as shown below). 3.2 The catalytic performance of Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 catalysts in the hydroformylation reaction The hydroformylation of 1-hexene was selected as a test reaction to optimize the catalysts and reaction conditions. The effect of Pt loading on the catalytic performance was first studied at a fixed Sn/Pt molar ratio of 5. As shown in Table 1 , negligible conversion was observed without Pt and the 0.9Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 sample was inactive either (Table 1, entries 1−2) under conditions of 90 °C, and 4 MPa syngas. With an increase of Pt loading, however, the conversion ascended steadily from 19.2 % on 2.9 Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 to 93.2% over 4.7 Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 (Table 1, entries 3−4), and then leveled off when the Pt loading was further increased to 7.7 wt% (Table 1, entry 5). Moreover, excellent regio-selectivities (linear/branched ratio > 40) were acquired in these catalysts, suggesting the PtSn/PS-PPh2 is a competent catalyst for the hydroformylation reaction. It is supposed the trend of catalytic activity with the loading of Pt might be related to the Pt/P ratios in the catalysts. Accordingly, control experiments using homogeneous Pt-PPh3 catalysts with different Pt/P ratios were carried out to verify this point. As shown in Table S1, the TOFs of the catalysts were indeed dependent on the P/Pt ratios, displaying a volcano relationship where the highest value was obtained at a P/Pt ratio of 1.5. A higher amount of PPh3 ligands blocked a portion of the Pt sites and thus reduced activity, whereas insufficient PPh3 ligands in the catalysts resulted in the hydrolysis of SnCl2 to generate SnO precipitates catalyzed by uncoordinated Pt species as discussed below. The ratio of Pt/Sn was also optimized. The conversion was only 6.9% with no aldehyde produced in the absence of SnCl2 (Table 1, entry 6). By contrast, the conversion was greatly enhanced to 65.9 % at Sn/Pt = 2.5/1 (Table 1, entry 7), and was further elevated to 93.2 % at Sn/Pt = 5/1 (Table 1, entry 4). The further increase of the Sn/Pt ratio, however, led to a slight decrease in the catalytic activity (Table 1, entry 8). Under optimum reaction conditions, although the catalytic activity of 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 was lower than that of Rh-based catalysts reported in the literature (Table S2), the regio-selectivity was superior to the latter. As Pt is much cheaper than Rh, and no delicately designed bidentate phosphine ligands are required to achieve high selectivity, the bimetallic Pt-Sn catalysts might serve as promising alternatives for the hydroformylation reaction. The other catalysts were also examined for the hydroformylation of 1-hexene. When SnCl2·2H2O were replaced by FeCl3·6H2O, HAuCl4·3H2O, or Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, the corresponding Pt-Fe/PS-PPh2, Pt-Au/PS-PPh2, and Pt-Zn/PS-PPh2 catalysts were hardly active for the reaction (Table 1, entries 9−11). On the other hand, when Pt(acac)2 was substituted by Pd(acac)2, although a high conversion was obtained over Pd-Sn/PS-PPh2 catalyst (Table 1, entry 12), the product was isomer of hexene and no yield of aldehyde was detected. The Pd-Fe/PS-PPh2 catalyst (Table 1, entry 13) also promoted the isomerization of 1-hexene although the catalytic activity was much lower than that of Pd-Sn/PS-PPh2. Rh/PS-PPh2 sample also delivered a high catalytic activity, yet the l/b ratio was only 3.2 (Table 1, entry 14), much inferior to that of 4.7Pt-Sn/ PS-PPh2. The addition of Sn to Rh/PS-PPh2 catalyst impaired the selectivity, i.e., not only a substantial amount of isomers was yielded, but also the l/b ratio was decreased to 1.1 (Table 1, entry 15). The solvent also had a profound impact on the catalytic performance (Table S3). Moderate conversions were achieved when the reaction was conducted in dioxane or toluene (Table S3, entries 1−2). By contrast, the catalytic activity was rather poor when cyclohexane was employed (Table S3, entry 3). To demonstrate the general applicability of the 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 catalyst for the hydroformylation reaction of higher alkenes, the scope of substrates was investigated. As shown in Table 2 , with the extension of carbon chains, the 1-alkenes were more reluctant to undergo hydroformylation reaction, and therefore long reaction time or high temperature/pressure were required to acquire an acceptable conversion. For instance, 93.2 % conversion of 1-hexene was obtained at 90 °C after 12 h reaction (Table 2, entry 2), while > 70 % conversion of 1-octene and 1-decene were achieved at 120 °C after 3 h with high regio-selectivity (l/b ≥ 20) (Table 2, entries 6 and 9). It was noted that the isomerization of 1-alkenes became prominent at 120 °C, leading to a great portion of isomers in the products (Table 2, entries 6 and 9). On the contrary, for 1-dodecene, high reaction temperature suppressed the isomerization instead, and the corresponding linear aldehyde was produced with a high yield (Table 2, entry 12) after 8 h. The pressure of syngas also had a remarkable effect on the product distribution, i.e., a low pressure promoted greatly the isomerization reaction arising from the β-elimination of the metal-alkyl intermediate (Table 2, entry 14), whereas a high pressure would promote the insertion step of CO and by which the side-reaction was suppressed (Table 2, entry 15). 1,7-Octadiene was also a good substrate and mono-functionalized 1-nonanal and 1-non-8-enal were produced with 36.9% and 54.1% yield, respectively (Table 2, entry 16). Cyclohexene was also tested for the reaction, however, negligible conversion was obtained probably owing to the high steric hindrance of this substrate (Table 2, entry 17). In the hydroformylation and other carbonylation reactions under high pressure of CO and/or H2, the in situ generated homogeneous metal carbonyls might serve as the genuine active species. We therefore carried out a hot filtration experiment to verify whether the catalysis follows a heterogeneous or homogeneous pathway. After the catalyst was separated from the reaction by hot filtration, the filtrate was allowed to stir for another 4 h under 4 MPa syngas at 90 °C, however, a negligible increase in the conversion was observed (Table S4). In addition, the concentration of Pt in the filtrate was below the detection limit of ICP-OES (Table S5), thus demonstrating the reaction was intrinsically mediated by a heterogeneous catalyst. Subsequently, we addressed the issue of recovery and reuse of the catalyst. The 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 sample was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation and reused in another batch of reaction after drying. Table S6 showed that the conversion significantly dropped to 21.1% in the second run and 10.1% in the third cycle, indicating severe deactivation of the catalyst. The spent catalyst was then subjected to characterization by XAFS and ICP-OES. EXAFS spectra showed no obvious Pt-Pt coordination was present, ruling out the possible aggregation of Pt after reaction (Fig. S2). The loading of Pt in the spent catalyst determined by ICP-OES examination was nearly identical to that of the fresh catalyst (Table S7), thus precluding the contribution of Pt leaching to the deactivation. By sharp contrast, it was found marginal Sn remained in the catalyst after the third recycle, suggesting SnCl2 could not be tethered by the PPh3 group on the support, and that the loss of SnCl2 led to the decay in catalytic activity. Accordingly, when a proper amount of SnCl2 (Pt/Sn = 1/5) was added to the reaction mixture in the fourth run, the catalytic performance was nearly completely recovered (Table S4, entry 4). Obviously, the durability of PS-PPh2 supported Pt single-atom species in combination with cheap SuCl2 is expected to provide a less expensive but highly regioselectivity alternative to the current much more expensive Rh-P catalyst systems. 3.3 Probing into the chemical state and coordination structure of Pt and Sn Quasi-in situ XAFS, Mössbauer spectroscopy, and FTIR were employed to probe into the chemical state and coordination structure of Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 catalysts in the hydroformylation reaction. First, the EXAFS data of the Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2-spent sample revealed a Pt-P contribution at 2.32 Å with coordination number (CN) of 3.9 and a Pt-Sn contribution at 2.64 Å with CN of 0.7 (Fig. S2 and Table S8). The presence of Pt-Sn metallic bond, in spite of low CN due to leaching of Sn, could still imply that Sn was coordinated with Pt acting as a ligand to modify the properties of Pt. The absence of Pt–Pt contribution suggested that Pt existed predominantly as single atom species, which was approved by HAADF-STEM image and XRD patterns (Fig. S3). The absence of Pt-C contribution and the relatively high CN of Pt-P contribution might arise from the ex-situ measurement of this sample, i.e., CO coordinates under quasi-in situ conditions would be substituted by phosphine upon exposure to air. Given the PS-PPh2 support material could not tether SnCl2 effectively as mentioned above, the homogeneous catalytic system (i.e., Pt(acac)2 + PPh3 + SnCl2·2H2O) with Sn/Pt ratio of 2/1 (denoted as PtSn2(PPh3)2) and an acceptable catalytic performance (Table S9) was then subjected to characterization to get high-quality spectra. For comparison, other two homogeneous control samples (denoted as PtSn2 and Pt(PPh3)2) were also prepared and characterized. As shown in Table 3 and Fig. 2(a) , for the PtSn2(PPh3)2 catalyst after the hydroformylation reaction, there was a Pt-C/O contribution at 2.02 Å with a coordination number (CN) of 4, a Pt-P contribution at 2.35 Å with a CN of 1, and a Pt-Sn contribution at 2.64 Å with a CN of 1.2. Obviously, the coordination structure of Pt for this homogeneous catalyst was quite similar to the solid catalyst Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2. The Sn-free Pt(PPh3)2 control sample presented similar Pt-C and Pt-P contributions to the PtSn2(PPh3)2 catalyst except for a Pt-Pt contribution at 2.75 Å with a CN of 2.4. The presence of Pt-Pt shell indicates the formation of Pt clusters, which is supposed to result from the reduction of Pt(II) by syngas. Evidently, the presence of Sn could protect Pt from reduction and aggregation. By contrast, for the sample PtSn2, there were Pt-C and Pt-Sn contributions with CN of 7 and 1, respectively. It is noteworthy that a peak at 2.93 Å also emerged, which was attributed to the Pt-Pt bond bridged by CO [38,39]. The appearance of this Pt-CO-Pt coordination, together with the relatively high CN of Pt-C contribution when compared to the other two samples, indicates the formation of clusters of platinum carbonyls. The coordination structure of Sn was also investigated. As shown in Table 3 and Fig. 2(b), three shells were present, i.e., Sn-C/O at 2.09 Å with a CN of 0.7, Sn-Cl at 2.42 Å with CN of 3, and Sn-Pt at 2.66 Å with a CN of 0.5 in the PtSn2(PPh3)2 sample. It is thus speculated that SnCl2·2H2O was transformed into Sn(C/O)Cl3 − species which were coordinated to the central Pt atoms in the catalyst. It is noted that the bond distance (2.66 Å) of the Sn-Pt shell was nearly identical to that (2.64 Å) of the Pt-Sn shell, further corroborating the formation of the Pt-Sn metal-metal bond. The chemical state of Pt and Sn was investigated by XANES. As shown in Fig. 2(c), for the PtSn2(PPh3)2 catalyst, the white line intensity, which reflects the oxidation state of Pt species, was much lower than that of PtO2 yet slightly higher than that of Pt foil, suggesting a chemical state of Pt(I). In the two control samples, the white line intensity was higher than that of PtSn2(PPh3)2, indicating a gradual increase of the oxidation state of Pt following the trend of PtSn2(PPh3)2 < Pt(PPh3)2 < PtSn2. The lowest valence state of Pt in the active PtSn2(PPh3)2 catalyst probably resulted from the electron transfer from Sn to P [40]. The Sn(C/O)Cl3 − species serving as a moderately electron-donating ligand, are expected to stabilize the Pt atoms with a low chemical state against aggregation, which was in sharp contrast to the Pt(PPh3)2 sample where Pt clusters were formed at the absence of Sn(C/O)Cl3. For the PtSn2 sample, it was found that black SnO precipitates formed after the reaction, which should arise from the hydrolysis of SnCl2 followed by dehydration. The concomitantly generated HCl might hinder the reduction of Pt(II) by syngas, leading to Pt species with the highest oxidation state. Notably, the formation of SnO was not found in all the other samples containing PPh3, suggesting the coordination of PPh3 to Pt could effectively suppress the hydrolysis of SnCl2 which process is supposed to be promoted by free Pt(II) species. The XANES spectra at Sn K-edge indicated there was hardly any change in the oxidation state of Sn(II) in the samples studied (Fig. 2(d)). Mössbauer spectroscopy measurements were then conducted to discriminate the different Sn species. Fig. 3 showed the Mössbauer spectra of the PtSn10(PPh3)1 samples before and after the reaction, and Table S10 listed the Mössbauer parameters as well as the relative proportions of different Sn species. According to the isomer shift (IS) and quadrupole splitting (QS) values, one singlet and three different doublets could be well identified in the two samples. Among the three doublets, the prominent doublet was assigned to Sn(II)Cl3 − species, and the one with slightly lower IS was attributed to PtSnCl3 species [41,42]. These results were in good agreement with XAFS measurements, further demonstrating the transformation of SnCl2·2H2O to Sn(II)Cl3 − species and also the formation of Pt-SnCl3 coordinating bond. The decrease in the proportion of PtSnCl3 species from 15.3% to 8.3% after reaction is supposed to be due to the replacement of Sn(II)Cl3 − by CO. The other doublet and the singlet were ascribed to Sn(IV) species, which should result from the oxidation of Sn(II) during the operation. As aforementioned, although the XAFS curve-fitting results suggested that both Pt and Sn were coordinated to a light element (e.g., C/O), it is difficult to ascertain whether C/O is corresponding to CO or 1,4-dioxane. Accordingly, quasi-in situ FTIR measurement was conducted. Fig. 4(a) shows the CO-adsorption band on different catalysts. No CO band was observed on Sn2(PPh3)2, while atop CO band at 2002 cm−1 and 2-fold bridging ones at 1855, 1812, and 1786 cm−1 were present on Pt(PPh3)2 [43,44]. The appearance of bridging CO band suggested the formation of Pt clusters, in good agreement with the XAFS measurement results. Compared with oxide supported Pt catalysts [45], these CO bands had remarkably red-shifted, indicating the PPh3 might impose an electron-donating effect on the Pt species. For the PtSn2(PPh3)2 sample, a prominent peak appeared at 1726 cm−1, which was assigned to ν(C=O) in the product aldehyde. The broad peak at 1996 cm−1 and the weak shoulder at 1960 cm−1 were ascribed to the symmetric and asymmetric vibration of Pt-CO in LnPt(CO)2 species, respectively [46,47]. The absence of a bridging CO band suggested Pt existed as single atoms. The 1,4-dioxane adsorption FTIR spectra are presented in Fig. 4(b). No adsorption of 1,4-dioxane on PS-PPh2 or 4.7Pt/PS-PPh2 was found, on the contrary, three characteristic stretching peaks assigned to 1,4-dioxane appeared on the 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 sample [48], demonstrating the coordination of 1,4-dioxane with Sn. Based on these results, it is confirmed that in the homogeneous PtSn2(PPh3)2 or supported 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 catalyst, Pt was coordinated to CO while Sn to 1,4-dioxane during the reaction, respectively. Taken together, the above results demonstrated both the in situ formed Sn(dioxane)Cl3 − species and the phosphine ligands were essential for the high catalytic activity of PtSn2(PPh3)2 in the hydroformylation reaction. The moderately electron-donating ligand of Sn(dioxane)Cl3 − derived from SnCl2·2H2O, stabilized the Pt(I) species with a low oxidation state against reduction and aggregation. The phosphine ligands, on the other hand, also contributed to the atomic dispersion of Pt through coordination, and thereby the intense hydrolysis of SnCl2 to SnO was effectively hampered. Although Mössbauer measurement revealed the existence of a great portion of free Sn(II)Cl3 − species, their possible role of acting as counter-ions was precluded, as other metal chlorides (Table 1, entries 9 and 10) might also serve as counter-ions, yet their combinations with Pt were inactive for the reaction. The reaction mechanism was then studied by control experiments with the PtSn2(PPh3)2 catalyst under different reactant atmospheres. As shown in Table S11 (entries 1 and 2), when H2 was first charged into the autoclave followed by CO (NOTE. Before CO was introduced, the reactor was flushed by N2 to completely remove H2), no aldehyde but hexane and isomers were detected, suggesting that the PtSn2(PPh3)2 catalyst was able to activate H2 and alkenes, and the formed metal-alkyl species can undergo either H addition to yield alkanes, or β-elimination to produce isomers. It was shown that much more isomers were yielded than alkanes, indicating the cleavage of H2 on the catalyst might follow a heterolysis manner [49]. On the contrary, when CO was first charged followed by H2, 6% aldehydes were produced, suggesting a strong coordination of CO on the catalyst even when the autoclave was evacuated (Table S11, entries 3−7). Based on these results and literature reports [33,37,50], a possible reaction mechanism was proposed (Scheme 1 ): The cleavage of H2 forming Pt-H species initiated the reaction, followed by the H addition to alkene to give Pt-alkyl species. The insertion of CO into Pt-alkyl produced Pt-acyl species, which then underwent reductive elimination with H to yield the product aldehyde. 4 Conclusions In summary, commercially available PS-PPh2 supported Pt catalysts promoted by SnCl2 were prepared and evaluated in the hydroformylation reaction of higher alkenes. The 4.7Pt-Sn/PS-PPh2 catalyst, with a Sn/Pt ratio of 5, affording high regio-selectivity to linear aldehyde (l/b > 20) and a TOF of 40 h−1. Long-chain alkenes, ranging from C6 to C12, underwent hydroformylation reaction smoothly to afford the corresponding linear aldehydes with high yields. It was found that the loss of SnCl2 resulted in the deactivation of the catalyst, yet with the addition of extra SnCl2, the catalytic performance could be recovered. Quasi-in situ XAFS and Mössbauer spectroscopy characterization were performed to elucidate the catalytic mechanism. It was found both SnCl2 and the phosphine ligands were essential for the catalytic performance. SnCl2 was transformed into Sn(dioxane)Cl3 − species during the reaction, which served as a moderately electron-donating ligand of the central Pt atom and thereby stabilized the Pt(I) species against reduction and aggregation. On the other hand, the phosphine ligands suppressed the hydrolysis of SnCl2 through coordination with Pt. This work might provide guidelines for the development of single-atom catalysts promoted by Lewis acids for other organic transformations. coredata.dc:description: Rh-P complexes have been widely used as catalysts for hydroformylation reactions. The extremely high price of Rh and its scarce reserves have prompted the exploration of the alternatives. In this study, we reported that Pt/PS-PPh2 single-atom catalysts promoted by SnCl2 were highly efficient and selective for the hydroformylation of higher α-alkenes. A broad scope of substrates (i.e., C6–C12) were smoothly converted to the corresponding linear aldehydes with high yields under reaction conditions of 90–120 °C and 4–6 MPa syngas. The turnover frequency (TOF) was comparable to homogeneous Pt-Sn catalysts, and the linear/branched ratio reached as high as > 20. In addition, the catalyst could be reused with the extra addition of SnCl2. The promotional role of SnCl2 was elucidated by quasi-in situ X-ray adsorption fine structure, Fourier transform infrared, and Mössbauer spectroscopy. It was discovered that SnCl2 was transformed into Sn(dioxane)Cl3 − species coordinated to Pt as a moderately electron-donating ligand, which, together with the phosphine group, stabilized mononuclear Pt (I) species against reduction and aggregation.
